column4: Insurer Chubb 'disappointed' as Hartford rebuffs more buyout offers
column5: (Reuters) -Property and casualty insurer Chubb Ltd said on Thursday it was “disappointed” that Hartford Financial Services Group had rejected two sweetened buyout offers, the larger of which valued the rival at nearly $25 billion.
column6: In its earnings report earlier in the day, Hartford said it had declined two offers from Chubb of $67 per share and $70 per share, respectively. The approaches came after Hartford rejected an initial $23.24 billion proposal.
column7: “Although we are disappointed, we want to repeat that our shareholders demand of us, and we demand of ourselves, that we remain a disciplined acquiror,” Chubb said in a brief statement.
column8: The mega-merger, which would be the biggest in the sector since Aon Plc’s $30 billion bid to buy Willis Towers Watson last year, would have given Chubb a strong presence in insuring small businesses.
column9: It would have also strengthened its business at a time when the industry is facing claims from companies that are losing revenue due to the coronavirus-driven cancellation of events.
column10: Chubb Chief Executive Officer Evan Greenberg warned last year that the coronavirus crisis would likely spur the single-largest loss in the industry’s history.
column11: Hartford’s latest rejections, however, do not come as a surprise as the company is worth $80 per share or more, according to analysts.
column12: Founded in 1810, Hartford famously sold baseball slugger Babe Ruth an insurance policy in 1920 for disability protection and also insured the only home Abraham Lincoln ever owned.

column4: Insurer Hartford to pay $650 million for claims linked to Boy Scouts of America sex abuse cases
column5: Insurer Hartford Financial Services Group (HIG.N) said on Friday it had agreed to a settlement with the Boy Scouts of America and would pay $650 million for sexual abuse claims associated with policies issued mostly in the 1970s.
column6: Under the agreement, the Boy Scouts and its local councils will release Hartford from any obligation under policies it issued, Hartford said.
column7: The Boy Scouts filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last February, amid a flood of lawsuits over allegations of child sexual abuse stretching back decades.
column8: "Our agreement with Hartford is an encouraging step towards achieving a global resolution that will promote the Boy Scouts' efforts to equitably compensate survivors and continue the mission of scouting," the Boy Scouts said in an emailed statement.
column9: The payment will be in addition to contributions from national Boy Scouts local councils, participating chartered organizations and other participating insurers, it added.
column10: Apart from Hartford, insurer Chubb Ltd (CB.BN) is also facing potentially massive liabilities stemming from the Boy Scouts of America bankruptcy.

column4: Hartford settles with Boy Scouts of America, to pay $650 mln for sexual abuse claims
column5: Insurer Hartford Financial Services Group (HIG.N) said on Friday it had agreed to a settlement with the Boy Scouts of America and would pay $650 million for sexual abuse claims associated with policies issued mostly in the 1970s.
column6: Under the agreement, the Boy Scouts and its local councils will release Hartford from any obligation under policies it issued, Hartford said.
column7: The Boy Scouts filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last February, amid a flood of lawsuits over allegations of child sexual abuse stretching back decades.
column8: "Our agreement with Hartford is an encouraging step towards achieving a global resolution that will promote the Boy Scouts' efforts to equitably compensate survivors and continue the mission of scouting," the Boy Scouts said in an emailed statement.
column9: The payment will be in addition to contributions from national Boy Scouts local councils, participating chartered organizations and other participating insurers, it added.
column10: Apart from Hartford, insurer Chubb Ltd (CB.BN) is also facing potentially massive liabilities stemming from the Boy Scouts of America bankruptcy.

column4: UPDATE 5-U.S. insurer Hartford fields takeover bid from Chubb
column5: Property and casualty (P&C) insurer Hartford Financial Services Group Inc (HIG.N)said on Thursday it has received a takeover bid from larger rival Chubb Ltd (CB.BN), which would create an insurance behemoth worth around $100 billion.
column6: "The Hartford's board of directors is carefully considering the proposal with the assistance of its financial and legal advisors" and will act "in the best interests of shareholders over the long term," the insurer said in a statement after Bloomberg News reported on the talks.
column7: The Hartford did not disclose financial details of Chubb's offer. The Hartford shares rose 19% to close at $68.15 on the news, pushing its market value past $24 billion.
column8: Chubb did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
column9: A deal between The Hartford and Chubb would be the biggest in the sector since Aon Plc's $30 billion acquisition of Willis Towers Watson last year, and the largest in the U.S. P&C insurance space since Chubb was created in its current form in January 2016.
column10: Then, ACE Ltd bought Chubb Corp for $28.5 billion, with the combined company retaining Chubb's branding.
column11: In a note, Wells Fargo analysts called The Hartford's small-business insurance franchise the main draw for Chubb, which currently focuses on covering mid-sized and large companies. Chubb has around $9.4 billion of excess capital to fund any transaction.
column12: They noted that previous deals in the P&C space valued companies at upwards of 1.8-times book value, likely seen as a baseline for negotiation by The Hartford, which traded at 1.14-times prior to Thursday's news. A 1.75-times valuation would price The Hartford at $30 billion.
column13: The cornoavirus pandemic is reshaping the insurance industry, and consolidation could help cut costs after substantial losses in 2020.
column14: Chubb Chief Executive Officer Evan Greenberg warned in April last year that the pandemic would likely spur the single-largest loss in the industry's history. The insurer booked $1.19 billion in pandemic-related losses in 2020.
column15: P&C insurers also faced significant catastrophe losses in 2020 from wildfires in western states and the most active Atlantic hurricane season on record. Combined with claims associated with civil unrest, these outweighed benefits from fewer auto claims as people drove less because of the pandemic, Fitch Ratings said in a report on Thursday.
column16: Chubb, which reported $41 billion of gross written premiums last year, also provides personal accident and supplemental health insurance, as well as life insurance, in 54 countries and territories.
column17: Founded in 1810, The Hartford reported $17.3 billion in total premiums last year. The company provides coverage for workers’ compensation, management and professional liability, and other specialized areas, including political risk.
column18: The Hartford famously sold baseball slugger Babe Ruth an insurance policy in 1920 for disability protection and also insured the only home Abraham Lincoln ever owned.
column19: Chubb traces its roots to 1882 when Thomas Caldecot Chubb and his son Percy opened their marine underwriting business in New York City.

column4: Insurer Hartford Financial to buy Navigators Group for $2.1 billion
column5: (Reuters) - Insurer Hartford Financial Services Group Inc HIG.N said on Wednesday it will buy Navigators Group Inc NAVG.O in a $2.1 billion cash deal to expand its product offerings and geographic reach.
column6: Hartford’s offer of $70 per share represents a premium of 9 percent to Navigators’ Tuesday close. Navigators’ shares were trading at $70.50, indicating that investors were seeking a higher offer.
column7: “Navigators does have a lot of structural things that make it look attractive to not just one acquirer but a lot of acquirers,” said Paul Newsome, analyst at Sandler O’Neill & Partners.
column8: “The markets are telling us that someone can come and give investors higher than what Hartford is offering,” he said.
column9: Navigators Group provides insurance services to marine, construction and energy industries, among other things, and has operations in 22 U.S. states.
column10: In addition to an established presence at Lloyd’s, Navigators also has growing underwriting operations in Europe, Asia and Latin America.
column11: Hartford said it had sufficient resources to fund the deal, and does not plan to offer shares in connection with the acquisition.
column12: The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2019, may slightly reduce Hartford’s 2019 earnings, but add between $30 million and $75 million to its net income in 2020, the company said.
column13: Citigroup Global Markets Inc was lead financial adviser to Hartford, with Deutsche Bank Securities Inc. Mayer Brown provided legal counsel to Hartford.

column4: Insurer Hartford Financial to buy Navigators Group for $2.1 billion
column5: Aug 22 (Reuters) - Insurer Hartford Financial Services Group Inc said on Wednesday it will buy Navigators Group Inc in a $2.1 billion cash deal.
column6: The offer of $70 per share represents a premium of 9 percent to Navigators Group’s Tuesday close. (Reporting by Diptendu Lahiri in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)
